segment.source: MDT 2013 Update 2 Lite Touch components (Windows 10)
segment.target: MDT 2013 Update 2 Lite Touch components (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic provides an overview of the features in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 that support Lite Touch Installation (LTI) for Windows 10.
segment.target: This topic provides an overview of the features in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 that support Lite Touch Installation (LTI) for Windows 10.

segment.source: MDT 2013 Update 2 Lite Touch components
segment.target: MDT 2013 Update 2 Lite Touch components

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic provides an overview of the features in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 that support Lite Touch Installation (LTI) for Windows 10.
segment.target: This topic provides an overview of the features in the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 that support Lite Touch Installation (LTI) for Windows 10.

segment.source: An LTI deployment strategy requires very little infrastructure or user interaction, and can be used to deploy an operating system from a network share or from a physical media, such as a USB flash drive or disc.
segment.target: An LTI deployment strategy requires very little infrastructure or user interaction, and can be used to deploy an operating system from a network share or from a physical media, such as a USB flash drive or disc.

segment.source: When deploying the Windows operating system using MDT, most of the administration and configuration is done through the Deployment Workbench, but you also can perform many of the tasks using Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: When deploying the Windows operating system using MDT, most of the administration and configuration is done through the Deployment Workbench, but you also can perform many of the tasks using Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: The easiest way to find out how to use PowerShell in MDT is to use the Deployment Workbench to perform an operation and at the end of that task, click View Script.
segment.target: The easiest way to find out how to use PowerShell in MDT is to use the Deployment Workbench to perform an operation and at the end of that task, click View Script.

segment.source: That will give you the PowerShell command.
segment.target: That will give you the PowerShell command.

segment.source: figure 4
segment.target: figure 4

segment.source: Figure 4.
segment.target: Figure 4.

segment.source: If you click View Script on the right side, you will get the PowerShell code that was used to perform the task.
segment.target: If you click View Script on the right side, you will get the PowerShell code that was used to perform the task.

segment.source: Deployment shares
segment.target: Deployment shares

segment.source: A deployment share is essentially a folder on the server that is shared and contains all the setup files and scripts needed for the deployment solution.
segment.target: A deployment share is essentially a folder on the server that is shared and contains all the setup files and scripts needed for the deployment solution.

segment.source: It also holds the configuration files (called rules) that are gathered when a machine is deployed.
segment.target: It also holds the configuration files (called rules) that are gathered when a machine is deployed.

segment.source: These configuration files can reach out to other sources, like a database, external script, or web server to get additional settings for the deployment.
segment.target: These configuration files can reach out to other sources, like a database, external script, or web server to get additional settings for the deployment.

segment.source: For Lite Touch deployments, it is common to have two deployment shares: one for creating the reference images and one for deployment.
segment.target: For Lite Touch deployments, it is common to have two deployment shares: one for creating the reference images and one for deployment.

segment.source: For Zero Touch, it is common to have only the deployment share for creating reference images because Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager deploys the image in the production environment.
segment.target: For Zero Touch, it is common to have only the deployment share for creating reference images because Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager deploys the image in the production environment.

segment.source: Rules
segment.target: Rules

segment.source: The rules (CustomSettings.ini and Bootstrap.ini) make up the brain of MDT.
segment.target: The rules (CustomSettings.ini and Bootstrap.ini) make up the brain of MDT.

segment.source: The rules control the Windows Deployment Wizard on the client and, for example, can provide the following settings to the machine being deployed:
segment.target: The rules control the Windows Deployment Wizard on the client and, for example, can provide the following settings to the machine being deployed:

segment.source: Computer name
segment.target: Computer name

segment.source: Domain to join, and organizational unit (OU) in Active Directory to hold the computer object
segment.target: Domain to join, and organizational unit (OU) in Active Directory to hold the computer object

segment.source: Whether to enable BitLocker
segment.target: Whether to enable BitLocker

segment.source: Regional settings You can manage hundreds of settings in the rules.
segment.target: Regional settings You can manage hundreds of settings in the rules.

segment.source: For more information, see the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit resource center.
segment.target: For more information, see the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit resource center.

segment.source: figure 5
segment.target: figure 5

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.source: Example of a MDT rule.
segment.target: Example of a MDT rule.

segment.source: In this example, the new computer name is being calculated based on PC- plus the first seven (Left) characters from the serial number
segment.target: In this example, the new computer name is being calculated based on PC- plus the first seven (Left) characters from the serial number

segment.source: Boot images
segment.target: Boot images

segment.source: Boot images are the Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) images that are used to start the deployment.
segment.target: Boot images are the Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) images that are used to start the deployment.

segment.source: They can be started from a CD or DVD, an ISO file, a USB device, or over the network using a Pre-Boot Execution Environment (PXE) server.
segment.target: They can be started from a CD or DVD, an ISO file, a USB device, or over the network using a Pre-Boot Execution Environment (PXE) server.

segment.source: The boot images connect to the deployment share on the server and start the deployment.
segment.target: The boot images connect to the deployment share on the server and start the deployment.

segment.source: Operating systems
segment.target: Operating systems

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, you import the operating systems you want to deploy.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, you import the operating systems you want to deploy.

segment.source: You can import either the full source (like the full Windows 10 DVD/ISO) or a custom image that you have created.
segment.target: You can import either the full source (like the full Windows 10 DVD/ISO) or a custom image that you have created.

segment.source: The full-source operating systems are primarily used to create reference images; however, they also can be used for normal deployments.
segment.target: The full-source operating systems are primarily used to create reference images; however, they also can be used for normal deployments.

segment.source: Applications
segment.target: Applications

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, you also add the applications you want to deploy.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, you also add the applications you want to deploy.

segment.source: MDT supports virtually every executable Windows file type.
segment.target: MDT supports virtually every executable Windows file type.

segment.source: The file can be a standard .exe file with command-line switches for an unattended install, a Microsoft Windows Installer (MSI) package, a batch file, or a VBScript.
segment.target: The file can be a standard .exe file with command-line switches for an unattended install, a Microsoft Windows Installer (MSI) package, a batch file, or a VBScript.

segment.source: In fact, it can be just about anything that can be executed unattended.
segment.target: In fact, it can be just about anything that can be executed unattended.

segment.source: MDT also supports the new Universal Windows apps.
segment.target: MDT also supports the new Universal Windows apps.

segment.source: Driver repository
segment.target: Driver repository

segment.source: You also use the Deployment Workbench to import the drivers your hardware needs into a driver repository that lives on the server, not in the image.
segment.target: You also use the Deployment Workbench to import the drivers your hardware needs into a driver repository that lives on the server, not in the image.

segment.source: Packages
segment.target: Packages

segment.source: With the Deployment Workbench, you can add any Microsoft packages that you want to use.
segment.target: With the Deployment Workbench, you can add any Microsoft packages that you want to use.

segment.source: The most commonly added packages are language packs, and the Deployment Workbench Packages node works well for those.
segment.target: The most commonly added packages are language packs, and the Deployment Workbench Packages node works well for those.

segment.source: You also can add security and other updates this way.
segment.target: You also can add security and other updates this way.

segment.source: However, we generally recommend that you use Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) for operating system updates.
segment.target: However, we generally recommend that you use Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) for operating system updates.

segment.source: The rare exceptions are critical hotfixes that are not available via WSUS, packages for the boot image, or any other package that needs to be deployed before the WSUS update process starts.
segment.target: The rare exceptions are critical hotfixes that are not available via WSUS, packages for the boot image, or any other package that needs to be deployed before the WSUS update process starts.

segment.source: Task sequences
segment.target: Task sequences

segment.source: Task sequences are the heart and soul of the deployment solution.
segment.target: Task sequences are the heart and soul of the deployment solution.

segment.source: When creating a task sequence, you need to select a template.
segment.target: When creating a task sequence, you need to select a template.

segment.source: The templates are located in the Templates folder in the MDT installation directory, and they determine which default actions are present in the sequence.
segment.target: The templates are located in the Templates folder in the MDT installation directory, and they determine which default actions are present in the sequence.

segment.source: You can think of a task sequence as a list of actions that need to be executed in a certain order.
segment.target: You can think of a task sequence as a list of actions that need to be executed in a certain order.

segment.source: Each action can also have conditions.
segment.target: Each action can also have conditions.

segment.source: Some examples of actions are as follows:
segment.target: Some examples of actions are as follows:

segment.source: Gather.
segment.target: Gather.

segment.source: Reads configuration settings from the deployment server.
segment.target: Reads configuration settings from the deployment server.

segment.source: Format and Partition.
segment.target: Format and Partition.

segment.source: Creates the partition(s) and formats them.
segment.target: Creates the partition(s) and formats them.

segment.source: Inject Drivers.
segment.target: Inject Drivers.

segment.source: Finds out which drivers the machine needs and downloads them from the central driver repository.
segment.target: Finds out which drivers the machine needs and downloads them from the central driver repository.

segment.source: Apply Operating System.
segment.target: Apply Operating System.

segment.source: Uses ImageX to apply the image.
segment.target: Uses ImageX to apply the image.

segment.source: Windows Update.
segment.target: Windows Update.

segment.source: Connects to a WSUS server and updates the machine.
segment.target: Connects to a WSUS server and updates the machine.

segment.source: Task sequence templates
segment.target: Task sequence templates

segment.source: MDT comes with nine default task sequence templates.
segment.target: MDT comes with nine default task sequence templates.

segment.source: You can also create your own templates.
segment.target: You can also create your own templates.

segment.source: As long as you store them in the Templates folder, they will be available when you create a new task sequence.
segment.target: As long as you store them in the Templates folder, they will be available when you create a new task sequence.

segment.source: Sysprep and Capture task sequence.
segment.target: Sysprep and Capture task sequence.

segment.source: Used to run the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool and capture an image of a reference computer.
segment.target: Used to run the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool and capture an image of a reference computer.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: It is preferable to use a complete build and capture instead of the Sysprep and Capture task sequence.
segment.target: It is preferable to use a complete build and capture instead of the Sysprep and Capture task sequence.

segment.source: A complete build and capture can be automated, whereas Sysprep and Capture cannot.
segment.target: A complete build and capture can be automated, whereas Sysprep and Capture cannot.

segment.source: Standard Client task sequence.
segment.target: Standard Client task sequence.

segment.source: The most frequently used task sequence.
segment.target: The most frequently used task sequence.

segment.source: Used for creating reference images and for deploying clients in production.
segment.target: Used for creating reference images and for deploying clients in production.

segment.source: Standard Client Replace task sequence.
segment.target: Standard Client Replace task sequence.

segment.source: Used to run User State Migration Tool (USMT) backup and the optional full Windows Imaging (WIM) backup action.
segment.target: Used to run User State Migration Tool (USMT) backup and the optional full Windows Imaging (WIM) backup action.

segment.source: Can also be used to do a secure wipe of a machine that is going to be decommissioned.
segment.target: Can also be used to do a secure wipe of a machine that is going to be decommissioned.

segment.source: Custom task sequence.
segment.target: Custom task sequence.

segment.source: As the name implies, a custom task sequence with only one default action (one Install Application action).
segment.target: As the name implies, a custom task sequence with only one default action (one Install Application action).

segment.source: Standard Server task sequence.
segment.target: Standard Server task sequence.

segment.source: The default task sequence for deploying operating system images to servers.
segment.target: The default task sequence for deploying operating system images to servers.

segment.source: The main difference between this template and the Standard Client task sequence template is that it does not contain any USMT actions because USMT is not supported on servers.
segment.target: The main difference between this template and the Standard Client task sequence template is that it does not contain any USMT actions because USMT is not supported on servers.

segment.source: Lite Touch OEM task sequence.
segment.target: Lite Touch OEM task sequence.

segment.source: Used to preload operating systems images on the computer hard drive.
segment.target: Used to preload operating systems images on the computer hard drive.

segment.source: Typically used by computer original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) but some enterprise organizations also use this feature.
segment.target: Typically used by computer original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) but some enterprise organizations also use this feature.

segment.source: Post OS Installation task sequence.
segment.target: Post OS Installation task sequence.

segment.source: A task sequence prepared to run actions after the operating system has been deployed.
segment.target: A task sequence prepared to run actions after the operating system has been deployed.

segment.source: Very useful for server deployments but not often used for client deployments.
segment.target: Very useful for server deployments but not often used for client deployments.

segment.source: Deploy to VHD Client task sequence.
segment.target: Deploy to VHD Client task sequence.

segment.source: Similar to the Standard Client task sequence template but also creates a virtual hard disk (VHD) file on the target computer and deploys the image to the VHD file.
segment.target: Similar to the Standard Client task sequence template but also creates a virtual hard disk (VHD) file on the target computer and deploys the image to the VHD file.

segment.source: Deploy to VHD Server task sequence.
segment.target: Deploy to VHD Server task sequence.

segment.source: Same as the Deploy to VHD Client task sequence but for servers.
segment.target: Same as the Deploy to VHD Client task sequence but for servers.

segment.source: Standard Client Upgrade task sequence.
segment.target: Standard Client Upgrade task sequence.

segment.source: A simple task sequence template used to perform an in-place upgrade from Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 8.1 directly to Windows 10, automatically preserving existing data, settings, applications, and drivers.
segment.target: A simple task sequence template used to perform an in-place upgrade from Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 8.1 directly to Windows 10, automatically preserving existing data, settings, applications, and drivers.

segment.source: Selection profiles
segment.target: Selection profiles

segment.source: Selection profiles, which are available in the Advanced Configuration node, provide a way to filter content in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: Selection profiles, which are available in the Advanced Configuration node, provide a way to filter content in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Selection profiles are used for several purposes in the Deployment Workbench and in Lite Touch deployments.
segment.target: Selection profiles are used for several purposes in the Deployment Workbench and in Lite Touch deployments.

segment.source: For example, they can be used to:
segment.target: For example, they can be used to:

segment.source: Control which drivers and packages are injected into the Lite Touch (and generic) boot images.
segment.target: Control which drivers and packages are injected into the Lite Touch (and generic) boot images.

segment.source: Control which drivers are injected during the task sequence.
segment.target: Control which drivers are injected during the task sequence.

segment.source: Control what is included in any media that you create.
segment.target: Control what is included in any media that you create.

segment.source: Control what is replicated to other deployment shares.
segment.target: Control what is replicated to other deployment shares.

segment.source: Filter which task sequences and applications are displayed in the Deployment Wizard.
segment.target: Filter which task sequences and applications are displayed in the Deployment Wizard.

segment.source: Logging
segment.target: Logging

segment.source: MDT uses many log files during operating system deployments.
segment.target: MDT uses many log files during operating system deployments.

segment.source: By default the logs are client side, but by configuring the deployment settings, you can have MDT store them on the server, as well.
segment.target: By default the logs are client side, but by configuring the deployment settings, you can have MDT store them on the server, as well.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The easiest way to view log files is to use Configuration Manager Trace (CMTrace), which is included in the System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager Toolkit.
segment.target: The easiest way to view log files is to use Configuration Manager Trace (CMTrace), which is included in the System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager Toolkit.

segment.source: Monitoring
segment.target: Monitoring

segment.source: On the deployment share, you also can enable monitoring.
segment.target: On the deployment share, you also can enable monitoring.

segment.source: After you enable monitoring, you will see all running deployments in the Monitor node in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: After you enable monitoring, you will see all running deployments in the Monitor node in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: Key features in MDT 2013 Update 2
